1.text: “Can you pull in Leviathan with a hook or tie down his tongue with a rope?

2.text: Can you put a cord through his nose or pierce his jaw with a hook?

3.text: Will he beg you for mercy or speak to you softly?

4.text: Will he make a covenant with you to take him as a slave for life?

5.text: Can you pet him like a bird or put him on a leash for your maidens?

6.text: Will traders barter for him or divide him among the merchants?

7.text: Can you fill his hide with harpoons or his head with fishing spears?

8.text: If you lay a hand on him, you will remember the battle and never repeat it!

9.text: Surely hope of overcoming him is false. Is not the sight of him overwhelming?

10.text: No one is so fierce as to rouse Leviathan. Then who is able to stand against Me?

11.text: Who has given to Me that I should repay him? Everything under heaven is Mine.

12.text: I cannot keep silent about his limbs, his power and graceful form.

13.text: Who can strip off his outer coat? Who can approach him with a bridle?

14.text: Who can open his jaws, ringed by his fearsome teeth?

15.text: His rows of scales are his pride, tightly sealed together.

16.text: One scale is so near to another that no air can pass between them.

17.text: They are joined to one another; they clasp and cannot be separated.

18.text: His snorting flashes with light, and his eyes are like the rays of dawn.

19.text: Firebrands stream from his mouth; fiery sparks shoot forth!

20.text: Smoke billows from his nostrils as from a boiling pot over burning reeds.

21.text: His breath sets coals ablaze, and flames pour from his mouth.

22.text: Strength resides in his neck, and dismay leaps before him.

23.text: The folds of his flesh are tightly joined; they are firm and immovable.

24.text: His chest is as hard as a rock, as hard as a lower millstone!

25.text: When Leviathan rises up, the mighty are terrified; they withdraw before his thrashing.

26.text: The sword that reaches him has no effect, nor does the spear or dart or arrow.

27.text: He regards iron as straw and bronze as rotten wood.

28.text: No arrow can make him flee; slingstones become like chaff to him.

29.text: A club is regarded as straw, and he laughs at the sound of the lance.

30.text: His undersides are jagged potsherds, spreading out the mud like a threshing sledge.

31.text: He makes the depths seethe like a cauldron; he makes the sea like a jar of ointment.

32.text: He leaves a glistening wake behind him; one would think the deep had white hair!

33.text: Nothing on earth is his equal—a creature devoid of fear!

34.text: He looks down on all the haughty; he is king over all the proud.”
